    <article class="markdown-body entry-content" itemprop="mainContentOfPage"><table data-table-type="yaml-metadata">
  <thead>
  <tr>
  <th>title</th>

  <th>author</th>

  <th>date</th>

  <th>output</th>

  <th>layout</th>
  </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>
  <tr>
  <td><div>Matrix Algebra Notation</div></td>

  <td><div>Rafa</div></td>

  <td><div>January 31, 2015</div></td>

  <td><div>html_document</div></td>

  <td><div>page</div></td>
  </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">knitr</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">opts_chunk</span><span class="pl-k">$</span>set(<span class="pl-v">fig.path</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>paste0(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>figure/<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, sub(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(.*).Rmd<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span><span class="pl-cce">\\</span>1<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,basename(<span class="pl-e">knitr</span><span class="pl-k">:::</span><span class="pl-smi">knit_concord</span><span class="pl-k">$</span>get(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>infile<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>))), <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>-<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>))</pre></div>

<h2><a id="user-content-matrix-notation" class="anchor" href="#matrix-notation" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Matrix Notation</h2>

<p>Here we introduce the basics of matrix notation. Initially this may seem over-complicated, but once we get to the examples you will start to appreciate the power of using this notation to both explain and derive solutions, as well as implement them as R code. </p>

<h3><a id="user-content-the-language-of-linear-models" class="anchor" href="#the-language-of-linear-models" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>The Language of Linear Models</h3>

<p>Linear algebra notation actually simplifies the mathematical descriptions and manipulations of linear models, as well as coding in R. We will show you the basics of this notation and then show some examples in R.</p>

<p>The main point of this entire exercise is to show how we can write the models above using matrix notation and then explain how this is useful for solving the least squares equation. We start by simply defining notation and matrix multiplication, but bear with us since we eventually get back to the practical application.</p>

<h2><a id="user-content-solving-system-of-equations" class="anchor" href="#solving-system-of-equations" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Solving System of Equations</h2>

<p>Linear algebra was created by mathematicians to solve systems of linear equations such as this:</p>

<p>$$
\begin{align<em>}
a + b + c &amp;= 6\
3a - 2b + c &amp;= 2\
2a + b  - c &amp;= 1
\end{align</em>}
$$</p>

<p>It provides very useful machinery to solve these problems generally. We will learn how we can write and solve this system using matrix algebra notation:</p>

<p>$$ 
\,
\begin{pmatrix}
1&amp;1&amp;1\
3&amp;-2&amp;1\
2&amp;1&amp;-1
\end{pmatrix}
\begin{pmatrix}
a\
b\
c
\end{pmatrix} =
\begin{pmatrix}
6\
2\
1
\end{pmatrix}
\implies
\begin{pmatrix}
a\
b\
c
\end{pmatrix} =
\begin{pmatrix}
1&amp;1&amp;1\
3&amp;-2&amp;1\
2&amp;1&amp;-1
\end{pmatrix}^{-1}
\begin{pmatrix}
6\
2\
1
\end{pmatrix}
$$</p>

<p>This section explains the notation used above. It turns that we can borrow this notation for linear models in statistics as well.</p>

<h2><a id="user-content-vectors-matrices-and-scalars" class="anchor" href="#vectors-matrices-and-scalars" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Vectors, Matrices and Scalars</h2>

<p>In the examples above the random variables associated with the data were represented by $Y_1,\dots,Y_n$. We can think of this as a vector. In fact, in R we are already doing this:</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r,message=FALSE"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">UsingR</span>)
<span class="pl-v">y</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">father.son</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">fheight</span>
head(<span class="pl-smi">y</span>)</pre></div>

<p>In math we can also use just one symbol and we usually use bold to distinguish it from the individual entries:</p>

<p>$$ \mathbf{Y} = \begin{pmatrix}
Y_1\\
Y_2\\
\vdots\\
Y_N
\end{pmatrix}
$$</p>

<p>For reasons that will soon become clear, default representation of data vectors have dimension $N\times 1$ as opposed to $1 \times N$ .</p>

<p>Here we don't always use bold because normally one can tell what is a matrix from the context.</p>

<p>Similarly, we can use math notation to represent the covariates or predictors. In the case of the two, the second one is just the square of the first.</p>

<p>$$ 
\mathbf{X}<em>1 = \begin{pmatrix}
x</em>{1,1}\
\vdots\
x_{N,1}
\end{pmatrix} \mbox{ and }
\mathbf{X}<em>2 = \begin{pmatrix}
x</em>{1,2}\
\vdots\
x_{N,2}
\end{pmatrix}
$$</p>

<p>Note that for the object falling example $x_{1,1}= t_i$ and $x_{i,1}=t_i^2$ with $t_i$ the time of the i-th observation. Also keep in mind that vectors can be thought of as $N\times 1$ matrices.</p>

<p>For reasons that will soon become apparent, it is convenient to represent these in matrices:</p>

<p>$$ 
\mathbf{X} = [ \mathbf{X}<em>1 \mathbf{X}_2 ] = \begin{pmatrix}
x</em>{1,1}&amp;x_{1,2}\
\vdots\
x_{N,1}&amp;x_{N,2}
\end{pmatrix}
$$</p>

<p>This matrix has dimension $N \times 2$ . We can create this matrix in R this way:</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">n</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">25</span>
<span class="pl-smi">tt</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> seq(<span class="pl-c1">0</span>,<span class="pl-c1">3.4</span>,<span class="pl-v">len</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">n</span>) <span class="pl-c">##time in secs, t is a base function</span>
<span class="pl-smi">X</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> cbind(<span class="pl-v">x1</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">tt</span>,<span class="pl-v">x2</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">tt</span><span class="pl-k">^</span><span class="pl-c1">2</span>)
head(<span class="pl-smi">X</span>)
dim(<span class="pl-smi">X</span>)</pre></div>

<p>Note that we can also use this notation to denote an arbitrary number of covariates with the following $N\times p$ matrix:</p>

<p>$$
\mathbf{X} = \begin{pmatrix}
  x_{1,1}&amp;\dots &amp; x_{1,p} \
  x_{2,1}&amp;\dots &amp; x_{2,p} \
   &amp; \vdots &amp; \
  x_{N,1}&amp;\dots &amp; x_{N,p} 
  \end{pmatrix}
$$</p>

<p>Just as an example, we show you how to make one in R, now using <code>matrix</code> instead of <code>cbind</code>:</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">N</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">100</span>; <span class="pl-smi">p</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">5</span>
<span class="pl-smi">X</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-k">matrix</span>(<span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">:</span>(<span class="pl-smi">N</span><span class="pl-k">*</span><span class="pl-smi">p</span>),<span class="pl-smi">N</span>,<span class="pl-smi">p</span>)
head(<span class="pl-smi">X</span>)
dim(<span class="pl-smi">X</span>)</pre></div>

<p>The columns are filled by column. The <code>byrow=TRUE</code> argument lets us change that:</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">N</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">100</span>; <span class="pl-smi">p</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">5</span>
<span class="pl-smi">X</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-k">matrix</span>(<span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">:</span>(<span class="pl-smi">N</span><span class="pl-k">*</span><span class="pl-smi">p</span>),<span class="pl-smi">N</span>,<span class="pl-smi">p</span>,<span class="pl-v">byrow</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">TRUE</span>)
head(<span class="pl-smi">X</span>)</pre></div>

<p>Finally, we define a scalar. A scalar is just a number. So why a special name? We want to distinguish it from vectors and matrices. We usually use lower case and don't bold. In the next section we will understand why we make this distinction.</p>
</article>
  </div>

</div>
